original_title: Richmond: Johnson Avenue - Arthur Kill Road
text:
(1) Johnson Ave. (or Shore Road), west side, about 700 yards north of Arthur Kill Road and 150 yards south of the shore of Arthur Kill, showing the Johnson (Johnston) House (1853-1874). In 1898 it belonged to G. C. Graves, and in 1907 to Louise M. Giegerich. In 1917 it was the property of Chas. W. Graves. The dates refer to maps on which the owners' names appear.

November 25, 1922.

By Wm. T. Davis through P. L. Sperr.

(2) A full front view of the house.

November 25, 1922.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Richmond: Arthur Kill Road - Johnson Avenue
text:
(1)
Arthur Kill Road, south side at Johnson Avenue (or Shore Road). The view shows a clay pit back of the road and the effects of soil erosion.
October 12, 1926.

P. L. Sperr,

(2)
The clay pit at a later date.
June 7, 1928.

P. L. Sperr,

(3)
One of the banks of the clay pit.
June 7, 1928.

P. L. Sperr,

original_title: Richmond: Johnson Avenue - Arthur Kill Road
text:
Johnson Ave. (or Shore Road), east side, 600 yards north of Arthur Kill Road, showing the International Ultramarine Works. The buildings are situated near the shore of Arthur Kill. The view is northward. Johnson Ave. runs north from Arthur Kill Road to Arthur Kill, midway between Ellis Road and Chemical Lane.

October 6, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Richmond: Arthur Kill Road - Johnson Avenue
text:
(1)
Arthur Kill Road, south side, at Johnson Ave. (or Shore Road). The view shows members of Clay Club and a monument of Staten Island clay constructed in an old clay pit near the abandoned railroad tracks of the International Ultramarine Works.
June 17, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A more distant view of the monument.
June 17, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
Members of the Clay Club at work on the monument.
June 17, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Richmond: Arthur Kill Road - Johnson Avenue
text:
Arthur Kill Road, south side, at Johnson Avenue (or Shore Road), showing the statue made by the Clay Club in an old clay pit.

June 20, 1928.

P. L. Sperr

original_title: Richmond: Johnson Avenue - Arthur Kill Road
text:
(1) Johnson Ave. (or Shore Road), west side, about 700 yards north of Arthur Kill Road and 150 yards south of the shore of Arthur Kill, showing the Johnson (Johnston) House (1853-1874). In 1898 it belonged to G.C. Graves, and in 1907 to Louise M. Giegerich. In 1917 it was the property of Chas. W. Graves. The dates refer to maps on which the owners' names appear. The view is southwestward.

October 6, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A view of the house in a northeasterly direction. Johnson Ave. runs north from Arthur Kill Road to Arthur Kill midway between Ellis Road and Chemical Lane.

June 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Richmond: Johnson Avenue - Arthur Kill Road
text:
Johnson Ave. (or Shore Road), north from a point midway between Arthur Kill Road and the shore of Arthur Kill, showing an old railroad track running beside the International Ultramarine Works. Johnson Ave. runs north from Arthur Kill Road to Arthur Kill, midway between Ellis Road and Chemical Lane.

October 6, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Richmond: Johnson Avenue - Arthur Kill Road
text:
Johnson Ave. (or Shore Road), east side, about 600 yards north of Arthur Kill Road. The view shows a pond near the International Ultramarine Works. Johnson Ave. runs north from Arthur Kill Road to Arthur Kill, midway between Ellis Road and Chemical Lane.

October 6, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Richmond: Arthur Kill Road - Johnson Avenue
text:
Arthur Kill Road, north side, 200 yards east of Johnson Ave. (or Shore Road). The house is situated 800 yards back of Arthur Kill Road, on the shore of Arthur Kill. In 1874 it was located on property belonging to J. Woglom, and from 1898 to 1917 the property belonged to the International Ultramarine Works. The dates refer to maps on which the property owners' names appear.

June 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Richmond: Johnson Avenue - Arthur Kill Road
text:
57 Johnson Avenue, east side, between Arthur Kill Road and Ellis Street, showing the Tottenville Hat Works.

April 23, 1929

P. L. Sperr

original_title: Richmond: Johnson Avenue - Arthur Kill Road
text:
Johnson Avenue (or Shore Road), east side, about midway between Arthur Kill Road and the shore of Arthur Kill. The house belonged to Donnally in 1874 and, later (1898 to 1917), to McCormack. It is about 100 yards south of the International Ultramarine.  Works. The dates refer to maps on which the owner's names appear.

June 17, 1929

P.L.Sperr
